channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Law Society says safeguards in new law will protect immigrants
item.description: The Law Society says immigrants can be reassured over new legislation after safeguards were introduced to protect them.

item.title: Live Covid-19 updates from New Zealand and around the world on 18 May
item.description: As up to 800,000 students head back to school today for the first time in eight weeks, many more parents are also able to return to their offices. Follow our blog for the latest.

item.title: Rates of gun crimes and killings using guns at highest levels in a decade
item.description: New figures obtained by RNZ show last year had the highest rates of gun crime and deaths involving firearms for nearly 10 years.

item.title: Firearms, drugs, $1m cash seized in police searches during lockdown
item.description: More than 90 people were arrested and nearly 50 firearms seized in a crackdown on organised crime during alert levels 3 and 4.

item.title: Cell phone tower attacks 'putting lives at risk'
item.description: The attacks - some of which have damaged the towers - is potentially putting lives at risk if it means people can't get through to 111.

item.title: When the tourism dollars disappear, what happens to Queenstown?
item.description: The Detail - A look at Queenstown's economic coronavirus bloodbath - and what it will take to recover.

item.title: Covid-19: 800,000 children return to school for first time in almost eight weeks
item.description: Teachers and principals are bracing themselves for all manner of reactions when 800,000 school children return to class today for the first time in eight weeks.

item.title: Playcentre movement directs funding 'outrage' at PM
item.description: Playcentre families, upset by last week's Budget, have been taking their fight to the Prime Minister, Jacinda Ardern.

item.title: Covid-19 pandemic 'spells the end of the neoliberal era'
item.description: The Covid-19 pandemic should be the occasion for people to consider whether the kind of society we've built is the kind of society we want, a philosophy professor says.

item.title: Rolleston fire put out
item.description: A burning mountain of tyres that spewed plumes of black toxic smoke in the Canterbury town of Rolleston yesterday has been put out.

item.title: What happened in NZ and around the world on 17 May
item.description: On a day when a young boy was the country's only new Covid-19 case, $265 million in government funding was announced for the sport and recreation sector to ensure it remains viable.

item.title: Homicide inquiry begins after injured man dies
item.description: Police have arrested and charged a 33-year-old man with murder in relation to the death of a man in ÅŒtaki yesterday.

item.title: One new case of Covid-19 in New Zealand today, linked to Rosewood cluster
item.description: New Zealand has recorded one new case of Covid-19, a boy under the age of four who is linked to the Rosewood rest home cluster in Christchurch.

item.title: Covid-19: Resilience crucial but may require 'huge shift in mindset', business coach says
item.description: A business coach guiding business owners through the wreckage of the Covid-19 crisis expects those under 40 will be hardest hit.

item.title: Firefighters battling huge blaze at property near Christchurch
item.description: A large tyre fire in Rolleston, a town near Christchurch has now been contained.

item.title: Researchers to study Covid-19's impact on children
item.description: Researchers and paediatricians are studying what information parents need about Covid-19 and its potential impact on children.

item.title: As it happened: Covid-19 updates for 17 May
item.description: As many NZers head back to work and school, they are being assured it is "completely normal" to feel anxious about it. See how the rest of the day's Covid-19 developments unfolded with RNZ's live blog.

item.title: Budget 2020: What you need to know
item.description: The government has unveiled a $50 billion recovery package as part of today's Budget. Here's a breakdown of where Budget 2020's money is going.
